description: Orchestration of CD4 T cell epitope preferences after multi-peptide immunization
study_description: A detailed understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms that underlie epitope preferences in T cell priming is important for vaccines designed to elicit a broad T cell response. Protein vaccinations generally elicit CD4 T cell responses that are skewed toward a small fraction of epitopes, a phenomenon known as immunodominance. This characteristic of T cell responses, that limits the diversity of CD4 T cell recognition, is generally attributed to intracellular antigen processing. However, we recently discovered that immunodominance hierarchies persist even after vaccination with synthetic peptides. In this study, we probed the regulatory mechanisms that cause diminished CD4 T cell responses to subdominant peptides after such multi-peptide immunization in mice. We have found that the delivery of subdominant and dominant epitopes on separate dendritic cells rescues expansion of less favored CD4 T cells. Furthermore, through the use of genetic models and inhibitors, we have found that selective losses in CD4 T cell responses are mediated by an IFN-gamma-induced pathway, involving indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO), and that regulatory T cell (Treg) activities may also regulate preferences in CD4 T cell specificity. We propose that after multi-peptide immunization, the expansion and differentiation of dominant T cells initiate complex regulatory events that determine the final peptide specificity of the elicited CD4 T cell response.

description: C57BL/6J Mice Are Not Suitable for Modeling Severe SARS-CoV-2 Beta and Gamma Variant Infection
study_description: To determine if mice infected with SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern without hACE2 can serve as models for severe COVID-19

description: Modeling the Impact of Vaccination Strategies for Nursing Homes in the Context of Increased Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Community Transmission and Variants
study_description: To examine the impact of community prevalence, the Delta variant, staff vaccination coverage, and booster vaccines for residents on outbreak dynamics in nursing homes

description: Variable cellular responses to SARS-CoV-2 in fully vaccinated patients with multiple myeloma
study_description: To determine whether seronegative vaccinated MM patients have detectable SARSCoV-2 B and T cell responses after SARS-CoV-2 vaccination

description: Sex Differences in Lung Imaging and SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Responses in a COVID-19 Golden Syrian Hamster Model
study_description: To explore sex differences using Golden Syrian hamsters in the pathogenesis of a human isolate of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

description: A bacterial extracellular vesicle-based intranasal vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 protects against disease and elicits neutralizing antibodies to wild-type and Delta variants
study_description: To evaluate efficacy of intranasal vaccination of golden Syrian hamsters using novel technology (bacterial extracellular vesicle-based SARS-CoV-2 vaccine)

description: A safe and highly efficacious measles virus-based vaccine expressing SARS-CoV-2 stabilized prefusion spike
study_description: To develop a safe, efficacious, and durable SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, using a measles virus (rMeV) vaccine strain as the backbone

description: Early Prediction and Longitudinal Modeling of Preeclampsia from Multiomics
study_description: The study developed a machine learning model for early prediction of preeclampsia (in first 16 weeks of pregnancy) and over gestation by analyzing six omics datasets from longitudinal cohorts of normotensive and preeclamptic pregnant women. The model had high accuracy in early pregnancy using urine metabolome and plasma proteome. A model using only nine urine metabolites had the highest accuracy and was validated on an independent cohort. Univariate analysis further confirmed statistical significance of all metabolites and proteins chosen by the prediction models. Longitudinal modeling revealed biological pathways associated with preeclampsia and confirmed known pathological alterations while suggesting novel associations between the immune and proteomic dynamics. The study identified several biological pathways associated with preeclampsia including steroid hormone biosynthesis (both early in pregnancy and over gestation), tryptophan and caffeine metabolisms (over gestation) and arachidonic acid metabolism (in early pregnancy). Integration with clinical variables further improved prediction accuracy of the urine metabolome model. The findings could lead to a simple, early diagnostic test for preeclampsia.

description: Oral Immunotherapy for Childhood Egg Allergy (CoFAR3)
study_description: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of the administration of oral immunotherapy (OIT). The intent is to develop desensitization and eventually tolerance to egg allergen.

description: Microbiome Preterm Birth DREAM Challenge
study_description: A crowdsourced approach was used to predict preterm and early preterm births from 9 publicly available vaginal microbiome studies representing 3,578 samples from 1,268 pregnant individuals, aggregated from raw sequences via an open-source tool, MaLiAmPi. The research was further validated with 331 samples from 148 individuals. Engaging 318 participants in the DREAM challenge, the study achieved notable predictive accuracy.

description: Maintenance and residence of immune memory to COVID-19 vaccines in tissues
study_description: Vaccines for COVID-19 establish protection through the generation of pathogen-specific antibodies in circulation, but whether cellular stores of memory are maintained in tissues is unclear. Here, we define the localization, phenotype, function, and tissue residency of memory T and B cells generated to COVID-19 mRNA vaccines across blood, lymphoid organs, and lungs.

description: Systems vaccinology of the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine in humans
study_description: We used systems tools to analyze immune responses in 56 volunteers who received two doses of BNT162b2

description: MoTrPAC 6-month rat endurance training
study_description: MoTrPAC is a national research consortium designed to discover and perform preliminary characterization of the range of molecular transducers (the molecular map) that underlie the effects of physical activity in humans. The programs goal is to study the molecular changes that occur during and after exercise and ultimately to advance the understanding of how physical activity improves and preserves health.

description: Randomized MMF Withdrawal in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (ALE06)
study_description: This trial seeks to describe the effect of withdrawal from mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) on risk of clinically significant disease reactivation in quiescent SLE patients who have been on long-term MMF therapy.

description: Secretory activity of human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells
study_description: Our research studied the effect of topographical cues of the culture substrate on the secretome of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells. Conditioned media and lysate samples of human bone marrow-derived mesenchynal stem cells cultured on the topographical substrates were sent to Raybiotech Inc. Services for protein detection. They performed a Quantibody® Multiplex ELISA of 200 human proteins. These results were used to further perform a differential statistical analysis on the expression of the quantified proteins using R statistical software. Differential protein expression and gene ontology analyses identified bio processes associated with immune regulation.

description: Genotype Polymorphism effects on Typhoid Vaccine responses.
study_description: Innate immunity gene products are known to be the first-line of host-defense and to control and assist the adaptive immune system. This research represents the opportunity to study, in detail, the responses longitudinally to vaccination (using clinical examination and laboratory assays) in a large ethnic population. Consequently, a prioritized set of genes and gene products from both systems will be evaluated.

description: CD8 Depletion
study_description: Cell-mediated immunity is critical for control of M. tuberculosis infection. Although the importance of CD4 T cells in control of tuberculosis is well-established, the importance of CD8+ lymphocytes is less clear. Here, we investigated the requirement for all CD8+ lymphocytes (innate and adaptive) or just CD8 alpha/beta adaptive T cells in control of initial and early infection in cynomolgus macaques, using anti-CD8alpha or anti-CD8beta depleting antibodies in vivo. Flow cytometry and single-cell RNA-sequencing analysis of lung granulomas from control (undepleted) macaques at 6 weeks post-infection revealed a rich landscape of cytotoxic CD8+ lymphocytes. Anti-CD8alpha antibody resulted in susbstantial loss of all CD8+ lymphocytes from granulomas, while anti-CD8beta antibody selectively depleted classical CD8alpha beta T cells. In CD8-depleted granulomas, CD4 T cells and gamma delta T cells had increased expression of certain cytotoxic effectors, such as granzymes. However, these cells had reduced expression of perforin, granulysin, and/or CCL5, and thus displayed an incomplete cytotoxic profile. At 6 weeks post-infection, CD8 alpha depleted macaques had increased granuloma numbers, lung inflammation, and total thoracic bacterial burden, while CD8beta-depleted macaques showed increased lymph node bacterial burden. Mtb barcode analysis revealed that depletion of all CD8+ lymphocytes resulted in greater initial establishment of Mtb in the lungs, indicating a loosening of the airway bottleneck for infection, and increased dissemination of Mtb within lungs, to lymph nodes and to extrapulmonary sites. These data suggest that the total CD8+ lymphocyte population is critical for early control of Mtb infection in macaques and support the importance of targeting CD8+ lymphocytes in a vaccine strategy.

description: Adaptive Immune Response to WNV
study_description: The Collaborative Cross mouse model was used to capture a wide range of cellular and cytokine adaptive immune responses to West Nile virus infection.

description: Drivers of Heterogeneity in Synovial Fibroblasts in Rheumatoid Arthritis.
study_description: Inflammation of non-barrier immunologically quiescent tissues is associated with a massive influx of blood-borne innate and adaptive immune cells. Cues from the latter are likely to alter and expand activated states of the resident cells. However, local communications between immigrant and resident cell types in human inflammatory disease remain poorly understood. Here, we explored drivers of fibroblasts-like synoviocytes (FLS) heterogeneity in inflamed joints of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients using paired single cell RNA and ATAC sequencing (scRNA/ATAC-seq), multiplexed imaging, and spatial transcriptomics along with in vitro modeling of cell extrinsic factor signaling. These analyses suggest that local exposures to myeloid and T cell derived cytokines, TNF, IFN, IL-1, or lack thereof, drive four distinct FLS states some of which closely resemble fibroblast states in other disease-affected tissues including skin and colon. Our results highlight a role for concurrent, spatially distributed cytokine signaling within the inflamed synovium.

description: Waning and boosting of antibody Fc-effector functions upon SARS-CoV-2 vaccination
study_description: Here we deeply profiled the functional humoral immune response induced by CoronaVac and Pfizer/BNT162b2 vaccines. Particularly we analyzed how the vaccine-induced functional responses waned with time and characterized the boosting capacity of the BNT162b2 vaccine, which enhanced the overall humoral responses of CoronaVac primed vaccinees to levels that were higher than the peak responses seen in the recipients vaccinated with two doses of the CoronaVac or BNT162b2 vaccines. We identified that Fc-receptor binding antibodies waned much faster than binding IgG1. Moreover, while antibody functions were induced against Omicron following BNT162b2 vaccination, these responses waned rapidly over time and were not observed in the setting of CoronaVac vaccination. Importantly, mRNA boosting of the CoronaVac response yielded a striking enhancement of functional humoral immunity across VOCs, including Omicron. These data collectively point to marked vaccine platform-based differences in peak functional humoral protection, as well as their distinct waning profiles. This phenotype can be enhanced and, in several cases, functionally expanded by heterologous boosting.

description: A serological assay for seroconversion detection
study_description: A serological enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay to detect SARS-CoV-2 seroconversion in humans

description: Respiratory mucosal immunity against SARS-CoV-2 following mRNA vaccination
study_description: To compare traditional humoral and cellular immune response with mucosal immune response to vaccination or infection (convalescent) and to test intranasal vaccination in a mouse model.

description: Durability of Booster mRNA Vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 BA.2.12.1, BA.4, and BA.5 Subvariants
study_description: To study the durability of booster mRNA Vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 Subvariants BA.2.12.1, BA.4, and BA.5

description: Retained spike-binding and neutralizing activity against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants
study_description: Post-vaccine sera were collected from participants in the PARIS study to determine neutralizing activity against 7 emerging variants

description: Neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 Variants of Concern Harboring Q677H
study_description: To investigate the neutralization sensitivity of variants containing the non-RBD mutation Q677H, including B.1.525 (Nigerian isolate) and Bluebird (U.S. isolate) variants

description: The COVID-19 vaccine concerns scale: Development and validation of a new measure
study_description: To develop and validate a scale for self-reported COVID-19 vaccine concerns among U.S. emergency medical services (EMS) and healthcare professionals.

description: COVID-19 Vaccinations in EMS Professionals: Prevalence and Predictors
study_description: To better understand EMS professionals decisions to receive or decline a COVID-19 vaccine

description: An Opportunity to Understand Concerns about COVID-19 Vaccination: Perspectives from EMS Professionals
study_description: To understand EMS professionals’ perspectives regarding COVID-19 vaccination

description: A Biomarker-based Pilot Study of Cockroach Sublingual Immunotherapy in Cockroach Sensitive Adults With Asthma and/or Perennial Allergic Rhinitis (BioCSI/ICAC-12)
study_description: There is currently no effective way to prevent development of allergic rhinitis (nasal allergies) and asthma and no cure. Sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT), a type of therapy in which allergens are placed under the tongue, may be a way to control and possibly prevent allergic rhinitis and asthma. However, detailed research of this approach is limited. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a sublingual cockroach extract given to adults with perennial allergic rhinitis, asthma, or both.

description: Closing the Gap on COVID-19 Vaccinations in First Responders and Beyond: Increasing Trust
study_description: To investigate the extent to which first responders in the U.S. trusted various information sources to provide reliable information about COVID-19 vaccines

description: Symptomology following mRNA vaccination against SARS-CoV-2.
study_description: To address existing information gaps regarding local and systemic symptoms in health care workers following mRNA vaccination against SARS-CoV-2.

description: Antibody responses to the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine in individuals previously infected with SARS-CoV-2.
study_description: To evaluate SARS-CoV-2-specific antibody responses after the first and second doses of the BNT162b2 (Pfizer–BioNTech) mRNA vaccine in a large and diverse cohort of healthcare workers.

description: Practice Patterns and Patient Outcomes After Widespread Adoption of Remote Heart Failure Care
study_description: To evaluate whether remote visits (video or telephone) were associated with different patient usage, clinician practice patterns, and outcomes.

description: Optimizing prevalence estimates for a novel pathogen by reducing uncertainty in test characteristics
study_description: To estimate the diagnostic test sensitivity and specificity through jointly modeling field data and validation data using standard Bayesian techniques.

description: SARS-CoV-2 Serosurveys: How antigen, isotype and threshold choices affect the outcome
study_description: To reveal the importance of evaluating serosurvey tools for antigen, isotype, and threshold-specific sensitivity and specificity, in order to interpret qualitative serosurvey outcomes reliably and consistently across study populations.

description: D614G Spike Mutation Increases SARS CoV-2 Susceptibility to Neutralization
study_description: The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) spike protein acquired a D614G mutation early in the pandemic that confers greater infectivity and is now the globally dominant form. To determine whether D614G might also mediate neutralization escape that could compromise vaccine efficacy, sera from spike-immunized mice, nonhuman primates, and humans were evaluated for neutralization of pseudoviruses bearing either D614 or G614 spike. In all cases, the G614 pseudovirus was moderately more susceptible to neutralization. The G614 pseudovirus also was more susceptible to neutralization by receptor-binding domain (RBD) monoclonal antibodies and convalescent sera from people infected with either form of the virus. Negative stain electron microscopy revealed a higher percentage of the 1-RBD ""up"" conformation in the G614 spike, suggesting increased epitope exposure as a mechanism of enhanced vulnerability to neutralization. Based on these findings, the D614G mutation is not expected to be an obstacle for current vaccine development.

description: SARS-CoV-2 -specific immune responses in boosted vaccine recipients with breakthrough infections during the Omicron variant surge
study_description: To analyze SARS-CoV-2–specific antibody and cellular responses in healthy vaccine recipients who experienced breakthrough infections during the Omicron surge.

description: Immune Responses to Seasonal TIV 2010-2011 Influenza Vaccination in Humans (see companion study SDY396,SDY564)
study_description: To use system biology approaches to compare differences in immune responses to vaccine

description: Neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron sub-lineages BA.1, BA.1.1, and BA.2
study_description: Examine the sensitivity of Omicron sub-lineages to neutralizing antibodies from mRNA-vaccinated, boosted and recovered COVID-19 patients.

description: Neutralization of the SARS-CoV-2 Deltacron and BA.3 Variants
study_description: To examine the ability of deltacron variants to evade immunity induced by either vaccination or previous infection

description: Perspectives of Volunteer Firefighters during the COVID-19 Pandemic: Stumbling Blocks and Silver Linings
study_description: To improve our understanding of the impacts of this pandemic on volunteer firefighters in relation to both their volunteer service roles and as members of their local communities

description: Ultrasensitive detection of salivary SARS-CoV-2 IgG antibodies in individuals with natural and COVID-19 vaccine-induced immunity
study_description: To assess the feasibility of a highly sensitive immunoassay method to detect IgG and IgA antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 spike protein receptor binding domain (RBD) in saliva from individuals with natural or vaccine-induced COVID-19 immunity.

description: Outcomes of Convalescent Plasma with Defined High versus Lower Neutralizing Antibody Titers against SARS-CoV-2 among Hospitalized Patients: CoronaVirus Inactivating Plasma (CoVIP) Study
study_description: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of nAb titer-defined COVID-19 convalescent plasma (CCP) in adults admitted to an academic referral hospital.

description: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) expressing the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 as a live virus vaccine candidate
study_description: Assessing and studying the potential neutralizing capacity of NDV vector vaccines expressing the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2

description: Convalescent plasma anti-SARS-CoV-2 spike protein ectodomain and receptor-binding domain IgG correlate with virus neutralization
study_description: The newly emerged severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) highlights the urgent need for assays that detect protective levels of neutralizing antibodies. We studied the relationship among anti-spike ectodomain (anti-ECD), anti-receptor-binding domain (anti-RBD) IgG titers, and SARS-CoV-2 virus neutralization (VN) titers generated by 2 in vitro assays using convalescent plasma samples from 68 patients with COVID-19. We report a strong positive correlation between both plasma anti-RBD and anti-ECD IgG titers and in vitro VN titers. The probability of a VN titer of greater than or equal to 160, the FDA-recommended level for convalescent plasma used for COVID-19 treatment, was greater than or equal to 80 percent when anti-RBD or anti-ECD titers were greater than or equal to 1:1350. Of all donors, 37 percent lacked VN titers of greater than or equal to 160. Dyspnea, hospitalization, and disease severity were significantly associated with higher VN titer. Frequent donation of convalescent plasma did not significantly decrease VN or IgG titers. Analysis of 2814 asymptomatic adults found 73 individuals with anti-ECD IgG titers of greater than or equal to 1:50 and strong positive correlation with anti-RBD and VN titers. Fourteen of these individuals had VN titers of greater than or equal to 1:160, and all of them had anti-RBD titers of greater than or equal to 1:1350. We conclude that anti-RBD or anti-ECD IgG titers can serve as a surrogate for VN titers to identify suitable plasma donors. Plasma anti-RBD or anti-ECD titers of greater than or equal to 1:1350 may provide critical information about protection against COVID-19 disease.

description: Preserved recognition of Omicron spike following COVID-19 messenger RNA vaccination in pregnancy
study_description: This study aims to test whether vaccine-induced antibodies raised during pregnancy continue to bind to and leverage Fc receptors to protect against variants of concern including the Omicron variant.

description: Humoral Responses Against SARS-CoV-2 and Variants of Concern After mRNA Vaccines in Patients With Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
study_description: To investigate vaccine-induced antibody responses in patients with NHL/CLL against SARS-CoV-2 strains

description: Functional Effects of Cardiomyocyte Injury in COVID-19
study_description: To use machine learning and in vitro models to identify plausible mechanisms of cardiac disease in COVID-19 patients.

description: Aerosol Inoculation with a Sub-lethal Influenza Virus Leads to Exacerbated Morbidity and Pulmonary Disease Pathogenesis
study_description: Examined how the method of inoculation affected immunity and disease pathogenesis in mice using mouseadaptedH3N2 A/Aichi/2/68 (x31)

description: Cas13d knockdown of lung protease Ctsl prevents and treats SARS-CoV-2 infection
study_description: To study whether targeting lung protease mRNA by Cas13d nanosystem represents a unique strategy for controlling SARS-CoV-2 infection and to investigate if CRISPR can be used as a potential treatment for SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: Immunogenicity of NDV-HRP-S in Sprague Dawley Rats
study_description: Assessing the immunogenicity of live Newcastle disease virus vector expressing a pre-fusion stabilized version of the spike protein, NDV-HRP-S, in Sprague Dawley Rats administered intranasally (IN), intramuscularly (IM), or IN followed by IM.

description: Reduced pathogenicity of the SARS-CoV-2 omicron variant in hamsters
study_description: To study if the pathogenicity of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron is less than that of prior SARS-CoV-2 variants in Syrian golden hamsters

description: Broad and potent activity against SARS-like viruses by an engineered human monoclonal antibody
study_description: To evaluate the binding activity and potency of ADG-2 against a large panel of sarbecoviruses

description: Cross-reactive coronavirus antibodies with diverse epitope specificities and Fc effector functions
study_description: To identify a panel of cross-reactive antibodies that recognize the S antigen from multiple coronaviruses

description: Neutralizing antibody vaccine for pandemic and pre-emergent coronaviruses
study_description: To evaluate the protective immunity of RBD-scNP adjuvanted with TLR7 and TLR8 agonist 3M-052 vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 and beta coronaviruses that circulate in macaques.

description: SARS-CoV-2 vaccines elicit durable immune responses in infant rhesus macaques
study_description: To assess the safety and immunogenicity of two SARS-CoV-2 vaccines (mRNA-LNP and Protein+3M052-SE) in infant rhesus macaques

description: COVID-19 vaccine mRNA-1273 elicits a protective immune profile in mice that is not associated with vaccine-enhanced disease upon SARS-CoV-2 challenge
study_description: To evaluate the immune response and potential for immunopathology in mice vaccinated with research-grade mRNA-1273

description: Role of miR-2392 in driving SARS-CoV-2 infection
study_description: To evaluate the role of a circulating microRNA, miR-2392, as a potential biomarker for COVID-19 and to develop a potential COVID-19 therapeutic and antiviral to inhibit miR2392.

description: Antibody binding and neutralization of live SARS-CoV-2 variants including BA.4/5 following booster vaccination of patients with B-cell malignancies
study_description: To determine the antibody responses after booster vaccination in patients with B-cell malignancies against SARS-CoV-2 variants including BA.4/5

description: Heterosubtypic Influenza infection antagonizes elicitation of immunological reactivity to hemagglutinin
study_description: Influenza-specific immunity in humans is unique because there are repeated exposures to viral strains containing genetically conserved epitopes recruiting memory CD4 T cells and novel epitopes stimulating naive CD4 T cells, possibly resulting in competition between memory and naive lymphocytes. In this study, we evaluated the effect of this competition on CD4 T cell and B cell response specificity using a murine model of sequential influenza infection. We found striking and selective decreases in CD4 T cell reactivity to nonconserved hemagglutinin (HA) epitopes following secondary influenza infection. Surprisingly, this shift in CD4 T cell specificity was associated with dramatic decreases in HA-specific Ab. These results suggest that repeated exposure to influenza viruses and vaccines containing conserved internal proteins may have unintended and negative consequences on the ability to induce HA-specific Ab to novel pandemic strains of influenza. These finding could have important implications on pandemic influenza preparedness strategies.

description: A bivalent SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibody combination does not impact the immunogenicity of a vector-based COVID-19 vaccine in macaques
study_description: To assess the impact of potent neutralizing SARS-CoV-2 mAbs on the immunogenicity of a genetic-based, prototypic viral vector-based SARS-CoV-2 vaccine when they are co-administered.

description: Enhanced neutralization resistance of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron subvariants BQ.1, BQ.1.1, BA.4.6, BF.7, and BA.2.75.2
study_description: To examine the neutralization resistance of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron subvariants BQ.1, BQ.1.1, BA.4.6, BF.7, and BA.2.75.2 against sera from vaccinated healthcare workers, hospitalized BA.1-wave patients, and BA.4/5-wave patients

description: Evasion of neutralizing antibody responses by the SARS-CoV-2 BA.2.75 variant
study_description: To examine the neutralizing antibody escape of BA.2.75 in mRNA-vaccinated and BA.1-infected individuals, as well as the molecular basis underlying the functional changes (including BA.2.75 infectivity, S processing, and fusogenicity)

description: In vitro and in vivo functions of SARS-CoV-2 infection-enhancing and neutralizing antibodies
study_description: To determine whether SARS CoV-2 RBD and NTD antibodies mediate enhanced immunopathology in macaque and mice, and if this enhancement will occur in the setting of human infection or vaccination.

description: Impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the total CD4+ and CD8+ T cell reactivity in infected or vaccinated individuals
study_description: To compare SARS-CoV-2-specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cells against the B.1.1.7, B.1.351, P.1, and CAL.20C lineages in COVID-19 convalescents and in recipients of the Moderna (mRNA-1273) or Pfizer/BioNTech (BNT162b2) COVID-19 vaccines.

description: Correlates of Neutralization against SARS-CoV-2 Variants of Concern by Early Pandemic Sera
study_description: To investigate cross-neutralization of the B.1.1.7 and B.1.351 SARS-CoV-2 variants in a well-characterized cohort of early pandemic convalescent subjects

description: Immune cells in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of Ugandan adults who resist versus those who develop latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection
study_description: Bronchoscopy was performed on 21 healthy long-term Ugandan RSTR and 25 LTBI participants. Immune cell distributions in BAL and peripheral blood were compared by differential cell counting and flow cytometry.

description: COVID19 SARS Vaccinations: Systemic Allergic Reactions to SARS-CoV-2 Vaccinations
study_description: Allergic reactions have been reported to occur after vaccination with both the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine and Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine. The reactions vary from mild to severe, including life-threatening anaphylaxis, but no deaths have been reported with either vaccine. This study is designed with two principal aims: To estimate the proportions of systemic allergic reactions to the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine and the Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine in a High-Allergy/Mast Cell Disorder (HA/MCD) population, and If the risk in the HA/MCD is demonstrable, to determine whether the proportions are higher in the HA/MCD in comparison to a representative population without severe allergies or mast cell disorders

description: Efficacy of Ustekinumab Followed by Abatacept for the Treatment of Psoriasis Vulgaris (PAUSE)
study_description: The purpose of this study is to determine if the use of ustekinumab, followed by abatacept, will prevent relapse in people with moderate to severe plaque psoriasis.

description: CALIBRATE ITN055AI: Rituximab Plus Cyclophosphamide Followed by Belimumab for the Treatment of Lupus Nephritis
study_description: In this experimental study, researchers will try to find out if treatment of lupus nephritis with a combination of rituximab and cyclophosphamide (CTX), or a combination of rituximab and CTX followed by treatment with belimumab is safe and if this drug combination can block the immune system attack

description: Specific CD4+ T cell phenotypes associate with bacterial control in people who ‘resist’ infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis
study_description: A subset of individuals with a high probability of exposure to M. tuberculosis (M.tb) appears to ‘resist’ established M.tb infection, as demonstrated by serially negative tuberculin skin test (TST) or IFN-γ release assay (IGRA) results. While these ‘resisters’ (RSTR) display IFN-γ-independent T cell responses to the M.tb-specific antigens ESAT-6 and CFP-10, it is currently unknown whether unique T cell functional programs are associated with this clinical outcome. We used multi-modal single-cell RNA, TCR sequencing, multi-parameter flow cytometry, and cytokine analysis in a discovery and validation format to compare the phenotypes and functions of M.tb-specific T cells between RSTRs and matched controls with ‘latent’ M.tb infection (LTBI). M.tb-specific T cells were clonally expanded in both RSTRs and LTBIs, confirming the priming of adaptive immune responses after M.tb exposure. However, M.tb-specific T cells derived from RSTRs showed enrichment of T regulatory as well as Th17-like functional programs compared to LTBIs, which were characterized by Th1*-like effector programs. Th17-like functional programs were also associated with a lack of progression to active TB among South African adolescents with LTBI, as well as bacterial control in published non-human primate studies. Together, these data suggest that ‘resisters’ may successfully control M.tb after exposure and immune priming and establish a set of T cell biomarkers to facilitate further study of this important clinical phenotype.

description: CD8+ T cells protect against CVB3 infection in females.
study_description: Coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) is the primary cause of viral myocarditis, and approximately 5% of symptomatic CVB3 infections are fatal. CVB3 infection also exhibits a strong sex bias, with males showing increased susceptibility to disease, which is incompletely understood. Despite these burdens, there are no vaccines or treatments available for Coxsackievirus infections. Using an oral inoculation mouse model to recapitulate natural infection, we demonstrated a sex bias where male mice succumb to CVB3-induced disease at an increased rate than female mice, consistent with human infections. Here we make the novel observation that CVB3 induces the expansion of antigen-experienced CD8+ T cells in female mice but not in male mice. The CD8+ T cells in female mice have an activated phenotype following infection, and we demonstrate that these T cells protect female mice from CVB3-induced mortality. Overall, our findings emphasize the importance of evaluating sex differences in the immune response to viral pathogens and may have implications for future T cell vaccine strategies.

description: JAX CCHI-Modulation of Lung Responses to Viral Infection – Microbiome
study_description: Elucidate the innate immune networks that shape adaptive immune responses to respiratory viral infections in the human lung. Define how inflammation driven by the microbiome dictates the steady state of tissue.

description: JAX CCHI-Modulation of Lung Responses to Viral Infection- ALI SARS-CoV-2
study_description: Spatiotemporally organized immunomodulatory response to SARS-CoV-2 virus in primary human broncho-alveolar epithelia. Use of lung donors from NDRI to make organoids, then lung organoid-derived air-liquid interface (ALI) cultures with infection of SARS-CoV2 like virus or mock. To better understand the early spatiotemporal events happening in lung epithelium during SARS-CoV-2 infection and their potential biological consequences, we based our study on an in vitro model of primary human airway epithelial cells: air-liquid interface (ALI) cultures generated from human lung organoids from healthy donors. Such cultures effectively recapitulate in vivo airway epithelium architecture and we validated their permissibility to viral infection by exposure to SARS-CoV-2 (Wuhan-like, USA/WA1-2020) and its variants (Beta, Delta and Omicron BA.1 subvariant). Our findings reveal spatiotemporal regulation of cytokines, chemokines and suggest that different cells in the lung epithelium may regulate different aspects of immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Furthermore, the use of lung organoid-derived ALI from a variety of donors revealed differential infection dynamics reflecting biological differences between individuals, potentially explaining some of the diverse clinical outcomes observed between patients.

description: Stability and heterogeneity in the anti-microbiota reactivity of human milk-derived Immunoglobulin A
study_description: This study investigates the antibacterial reactivity of breastmilk derived immunoglobulin A (BrmIgA) with an array of bacterial isolates commonly found in the preterm infant microbiota. We isolated BrmIgA from de-identified donors and use flow cytometry to characterize the intensity of antibacterial reactivity. Our results show heterogeneity of inter-donor BrmIgA reactivity but intra-donor stability over time. In addition, there was no significant difference in IgA concentration or reactivity between preterm and term donor milk. Lastly, we found that holder pasteurization globally reduces BrmIgA reactivity.

description: Myeloid-specific KDM6B inhibition sensitizes Glioblastoma to PD1 blockade
study_description: Targeting epigenetic pathways to reprogram the functional phenotype of immune-suppressive myeloid cells to overcome resistance to ICT remains unexplored. Single-cell and spatial transcriptomic analysis of human GBM tumors demonstrated high expression of an epigenetic enzyme- histone 3 lysine 27 demethylase (KDM6B) in the intra-tumoral immune-suppressive myeloid cell subsets. Using preclinical models of GBM with genetic deletion of KDM6B and pharmacological inhibition of KDM6B along with ICT, we assessed the reprogramming of the myeloid cells in the GBM tumor microenvironment.

description: UFDI HIP
study_description: Flow cytometric immune profiling on peripheral blood of T1D patients, their relatives, pre-T1D, and autoantibody negative healthy controls.

description: Genotype Polymorphism effects on Cholera Vaccine responses.
study_description: Innate immunity gene products are known to be the first-line of host-defense and to control and assist the adaptive immune system. This research represents the opportunity to study, in detail, the responses longitudinally to vaccination (using clinical examination and laboratory assays) in a large ethnic population. Consequently, a prioritized set of genes and gene products from both systems will be evaluated.

description: Predictive computational modeling of the mucosal immune responses during Helicobacter pylori infection
study_description: We developed a validated mathematical and computation model of immune responses to H. pylori infection that delineate how immune responses to H. pylori correlate with initiation, progression and outcome of disease.

description: 35th Multicenter Airway Research Collaboration (MARC-35): EWAS analysis of infants
study_description: In a multicenter prospective cohort study of infants hospitalized with bronchiolitis, we profiled their epigenome-wide blood DNA methylation level at hospitalization using Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip. We found that blood DNA methylation signatures were associated with bronchiolitis severity and various respiratory and immune traits.

description: Immune characterization of lung tumors by flow cytometry
study_description: Characterization of tumor immune compartment in an endogenous mouse model of lung adenocarcinoma after chronic bacterial instillation

description: Molecular signatures in a Hepatitis B Vaccine-immunized neonatal Tissue Construct in vitro correlate with antibody response in vivo
study_description: We employ our 3-dimensional tissue construct model that was previously used to investigate and replicate human age- specific vaccine responses in vivo, to a) gain insights into vaccine-induced OMIC signatures after single vs combined vaccination and b) investigate the association between human in vitro OMIC signatures and human in vivo hepatitis B antibody titers, a universally-accepted correlate of vaccine-induced protection.

description: Estimating Vaccine Efficacy Against Transmission via Effect on Viral Load
study_description: To assess the estimations of vaccine efficacy on transmission of SARS-CoV-2, with the use of quantitative data from virologic testing on a sample of trial participants.

description: Seasonal COVID-19 surge related hospital volumes and case fatality rates
study_description: To characterize how the 2020 winter surge in COVID-19 volumes impacted case fatality in an adequately-resourced health system.

description: Seroprevalence of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 in healthcare workers: a cross-sectional study
study_description: To determine the extent of SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence and the factors associated with seroprevalence across a diverse cohort of healthcare workers.

description: Infection and Vaccine-Induced Neutralizing-Antibody Responses to the SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617 Variants
study_description: To assess infection and vaccine-Induced Neutralizing-Antibody activity against the SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617.1 (or kappa) and B.1.617.2 (or delta) variants.

description: Neutralization Escape by SARS-CoV-2 Omicron Subvariants BA.2.12.1, BA.4, and BA.5
study_description: To evaluate neutralizing antibody titers against the reference WA1/2020 isolate of SARS-CoV-2 along with omicron subvariants BA.1, BA.2, BA.2.12.1, and BA.4 or BA.5 in vaccinated /boosted and infected participants

description: Determinants of human NK cell diversity by mass cytometry
study_description: Natural Killer (NK) cells play critical roles in immune defense and reproduction, yet remain the most poorly understood lymphocyte population. Because their activation is controlled by a variety of combinatorially expressed activating and inhibitory receptors, NK cell diversity and function are closely linked. To provide an unprecedented understanding of NK cell repertoire diversity, we used mass cytometry to simultaneously analyze 35 parameters, including 28 NK cell receptors, on peripheral blood NK cells from five sets of monozygotic twins and twelve unrelated donors of defined HLA and killer cell immunoglobulin-like receptor (KIR) genotype. This analysis revealed a remarkable degree of NK cell diversity, with an estimated 6,000-30,000 phenotypic populations within an individual and >100,000 phenotypes in this population. Genetics largely determined inhibitory receptor expression, whereas activation receptor expression was heavily environmentally influenced. Therefore, NK cells may maintain self-tolerance through strictly regulated expression of inhibitory receptors, while using adaptable expression patterns of activating and costimulatory receptors to respond to pathogens and tumors. These findings further suggest the possibility that discrete NK cell subpopulations could be harnessed for immunotherapeutic strategies in the settings of infection, reproduction, and transplantation

description: Immunity induced by vaccination with recombinant influenza B virus neuraminidase protein breaks viral transmission chains in guinea pigs in an exposure intensity-dependent manner
study_description: The authors investigated if recombinant influenza virus neuraminidase (NA) vaccines delivered at a mucosal site could protect from onward transmission of influenza B viruses in the guinea pig model.

description: Humoral profiling of pediatric patients with cancer reveals robust immunity following anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccination superior to natural infection
study_description: To evaluate the humoral and cellular immune response to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination in pediatric patients who previously received or are on active chemotherapy.

description: BCG vaccination history associates with decreased SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence across a diverse cohort of health care workers
study_description: To determine whether a history of BCG vaccination might be beneficial in preventing SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19 severity

description: Immunogenicity of homologous versus heterologous B mHA WIVs in mice
study_description: A head-to-head comparision of the immuogenicity of the homologous verus heterologous B mHA WIV in mice. The immunization groups include those in B mHA-immuno-01 and B mHA-immuno-02 studies using AddaVax as the adjuvant. A duplicate set of groups were immunized in the absence of the adjuvant. Passive transfer/challenge studies against multiple influenza B virus strains will be performed using sera from the terminal bleeding.

description: COVID-19 Booster Uptake among First Responders and Their Household Members May Be Lower than Anticipated
study_description: To understand whether vaccine hesitancy exists for first responders and their household contacts around COVID-19 boosters

description: Mucosal nanobody IgA as inhalable and affordable prophylactic and therapeutic treatment against SARS-CoV-2 and emerging variants
study_description: To test if intranasal administration of VHH-IgA fusion protein provides effective prophylactic and therapeutic treatment against infection of SARS-CoV-2 including emerging variants in mice.

description: mRNA-1273 vaccine-induced antibodies maintain Fc effector functions across SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern
study_description: To evaluate the binding and functional capacity of convalescent, mRNA1273 vaccine induced antibodies across SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern.

description: The Kinetics of SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Development Is Associated with Clearance of RNAemia
study_description: To examine the relationship of SARS-CoV-2-specific humoral immune evolution in the setting of SARS-CoV-2 plasma RNAemia.

description: Serological Markers of SARS-CoV-2 Reinfection
study_description: To identify simple, rapid immune biomarkers of reinfection in rhesus macaques that are recapitulated in human reinfection cases.

description: Compromised Humoral Functional Evolution Tracks with SARS-CoV-2 Mortality
study_description: To understand how antibody functions, beyond neutralization, evolve during SARS-CoV-2 infection and contribute to recovery in the broader population.

description: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination elicits robust antibody responses in children
study_description: To profile the vaccine-induced humoral immune response in children receiving either a pediatric or adult dose of the mRNA-1273 vaccine and to compare these responses to vaccinated adults, infected children, and children who experienced multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C).

description: Selective transfer of maternal antibodies in preterm and fullterm children
study_description: To investigate whether placental Fc-preferential transfer occurs constantly through-out pregnancy or evolves over time and whether the increased susceptibility of PT children is related to an impairment in the immune system or due to incomplete transfer of protective antibodies from the mother to neonate.

description: Humoral signatures of protective and pathological SARS-CoV-2 infection in children
study_description: To evaluate the pathological role of IgA and monocyte activating antibodies in COVID-19 and multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C).

description: Case-Control Study of Individuals with Discrepant Nucleocapsid and Spike Protein SARS-CoV-2 IgG Results
study_description: To use limited prospectively-collected data to assess inter-assay concordance of two widely used assays and provide interpretation guidance for discrepant results

description: Functional convalescent plasma antibodies and pre-infusion titers shape the early severe COVID-19 immune response
study_description: To assess SARS-CoV-2 specific immune responses with deep profiling (including measurement of SARS-CoV-2 Spike- and Nucleocapsid-specific antibody titers, Fc-receptor binding, and Fc-driven antibody functions) in hospitalized COVID-19 patients before and after Convalescent Plasma administration.

description: Evaluation of SARS-CoV-2 total antibody detection via a lateral flow nanoparticle fluorescence immunoassay
study_description: To evaluate the performance of the lateral flow QIAreach anti-SARS-CoV-2 Total rapid nanoparticle fluorescence immunoassay compared to reference isotype-specific IgG, IgM, and IgA SARS-CoV-2 ELISA using S1 or receptor binding domain (RBD) as antigens.

description: Compromised SARS-CoV-2-specific placental antibody transfer
study_description: To investigate whether placental antibody transfer dynamics shift with SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: Mouse Adapted SARS-CoV-2 (MA10) Viral Infection Induces Neuroinflammation in Standard Laboratory Mice
study_description: To study if SARS-CoV-2 (MA10) infection in laboratory mice is a clinically relevant laboratory mouse model for SARS-CoV-2-mediated cerebrovascular pathology.

description: Nplate® PK/PD Study with or without Neulasta® in Rhesus Macaque
study_description: Study to characterize the pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) profile of the test item, romiplostim (Nplate®), following one or two subcutaneous administrations to irradiated (target LD30/45) rhesus macaque non-human primates (NHP), with or without subcutaneous administration of pegfilgrastim (Neulasta®).

description: Reduced antibody activity against SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617.2 delta virus in serum of mRNA-vaccinated individuals receiving tumor necrosis factor-α inhibitors
study_description: To evaluate serum antibody responses in individuals with chronic inflammatory disease after immunization with the Pfizer BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine.

description: Autoantibodies are highly prevalent in non-SARS-CoV-2 respiratory infections and critical illness
study_description: To evaluate the prevalence of anti-cytokine and autoantibodies across non-SARS-CoV-2 viral and, nonviral infections and range in severity of illness.

description: Hybrid immunity expands the functional humoral footprint of both mRNA and vector-based SARS-CoV-2 vaccines
study_description: To define whether hybrid immunity shapes the humoral immune response to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) following Pfizer/BNT162b2, Moderna mRNA-1273, ChadOx1/AZD1222, and Ad26.COV2.S vaccination

description: Fab and Fc contribute to maximal protection against SARS-CoV-2 following NVX-CoV2373 subunit vaccine with Matrix-M vaccination
study_description: To define the specific humoral profiles that track with protective immunity against disease and infection after NVX-CoV2373 vaccination in primates and to define whether similar functional humoral profiles are elicited in humans.

description: Durable protection against the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant is induced by an adjuvanted subunit vaccine
study_description: To evaluate the durability of immune protection after a booster immunization with RBD-Wu or RBD-beta against the immune-evasive Omicron BA.1 variant.

description: Phosphatidylserine receptors enhance SARS-CoV-2 infection
study_description: To evaluate whether Phosphatidylserine (PS) receptors enhance infection of the pandemic coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and to suggest that inhibition of the PS receptor AXL has therapeutic potential against SARS-CoV-2.

description: Early cross-coronavirus reactive signatures of humoral immunity against COVID-19
study_description: To define humoral profiles that could predict differences in clinical trajectory after SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: COVID-19 booster dose induces robust antibody response in pregnant, lactating, and nonpregnant women
study_description: To profile the humoral immune response to a COVID-19 messenger RNA booster dose in a cohort of pregnant, lactating, and nonpregnant age-matched women

description: Immunogenicity and protective efficacy of a rhesus adenoviral vaccine targeting conserved COVID-19 replication transcription complex
study_description: To determine if vaccine-elicited T-cell responses to the highly conserved regions of the coronavirus replication transcription complex would reduce viral loads following challenge with SARS-CoV-2 in mice.

description: Obesity and Metabolic Dysregulation in Children, a Prospective Study
study_description: A prospective cohort study evaluating influenza vaccine responses in healthy and obese children.

description: A Combination Adjuvant for SARS-CoV-2
study_description: An intranasal, rationally designed adjuvant integrating a nanoemulsion (NE) that activates TLRs and NLRP3 with an RNA agonist of RIG-I (IVT DI).

description: Variable cellular responses to SARS-CoV-2 in fully vaccinated patients with multiple myeloma
study_description: To determine whether MM patients without detectable anti-S IgG antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 immunization (seronegative) had detectable SARS-CoV-2 B and T cell responses after SARS-CoV-2 vaccination, which would possibly provide some protection against severe disease even in the absence of anti-S antibodies.

description: Antigen modifications improve mRNA-based influenza virus vaccines
study_description: Nucleoside-modified, lipid nanoparticle-encapsulated mRNAs have recently emerged as suitable vaccines for influenza viruses and other pathogens in part because the platform allows delivery of multiple antigens in a single immunization. mRNA vaccines allow for easy antigen modification, enabling rapid iterative design. Here, we studied protein modifications which could improve the safety and/or potency of mRNA-based influenza virus vaccines.

description: First exposure to the pandemic H1N1 virus induced broadly neutralizing antibodies targeting hemagglutinin head epitopes
study_description: Guthmiller et al. passively transferred monclonal antibody cocktails (antibodies produced by B cells responding to the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus) to BALB/c mice, who were then intranasally challenged to observe whether the mice were protected from lethal infection.

description: A hemagglutinin-based universal flu vaccine
study_description: Men and women aged 18-39 yr that were healthy and of non-childbearing potential were enrolled into five groups to receive vaccinations with live-attenuated followed by AS03-adjuvanted inactivated vaccine, live-attenuated followed by inactivated vaccine, twice AS03-adjuvanted inactivated vaccine or placebo 3 months apart.

description: Oxidized DNA fragments exit mitochondria via mPTP- and VDAC-dependent channels to activate NLRP3 inflammasome and interferon signaling
study_description: To understand how and in which form oxidized Mitochondrial DNA (Ox-mtDNA) exits stressed mitochondria in non-apoptotic macrophages to activate NLRP3 inflammasome and interferon signaling.

description: The Serological Sciences Network (SeroNet) for COVID-19: Depth and Breadth of Serology Assays and Plans for Assay Harmonization
study_description: To study the immune response to COVID-19, and to develop, validate, improve, and implement serological testing and associated technologies.

description: Nsp1 protein of SARS-CoV-2 disrupts the mRNA export machinery to inhibit host gene expression
study_description: To examine if the virulence factor Nsp1 protein of SARS-CoV-2 interacts with the host messenger RNA (mRNA) export receptor heterodimer NXF1-NXT1

description: Multiomics signals associated with maternal epidemiological factors contributing to preterm birth in low- and middle-income countries
study_description: This study investigated the complex causes of preterm birth (PTB) using multiomic profiling and multivariate modeling. It analyzed plasma samples from 231 out of 13,841 pregnant women, identifying biological signatures linked to PTB and maternal characteristics such as maternal age, gravidity, and BMI. Machine learning models accurately predicted PTB, time-to-delivery, maternal age, gravidity, and BMI. The study revealed specific biological correlates for these factors and offered an integrated perspective on the epidemiological factors related to PTB.

description: Comparative analysis of vaginal microbiota sampling using menstrual cups and high vaginal swabs in pregnant women living with HIV-1 infection
study_description: Objective: To compare the efficacy of menstrual cups and high vaginal swabs (HVS) in collecting bacterial biomass for 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing. Samples: Cervicovaginal fluid samples from 16 HIV-1 infected pregnant women. Method for endpoints: Samples were taken with both HVS and menstrual cups, followed by DNA extraction, bacterial 16S RNA amplicon sequencing, and data analysis using MOTHUR, MicrobiomeAnalyst, SPSS, and R. The total DNA, bacterial load, amplicon read counts, diversity matrices, and bacterial taxa were compared. Main Result: Both menstrual cups and HVS are suitable for assessing vaginal microbiota composition and diversity in HIV-1 pregnant individuals, with menstrual cups offering some advantages like higher total sample volume.

description: Safety, tolerability, and acceptability of Lactobacillus crispatus CTV-05 (LACTIN-V) in pregnant women at high-risk of preterm birth
study_description: The study investigated the safety and acceptability of LACTIN-V (Lactobacillus crispatus CTV-05) in 61 pregnant women at high risk of preterm birth (PTB). Administered for five consecutive days and then weekly for six weeks, LACTIN-V demonstrated high compliance (93%) and only 19% reported adverse events. A substantial 97% of participants would use it in future pregnancies. The PTB rate was 3.3% before 34 weeks, lower than the 7% in a historical cohort. The findings suggest that LACTIN-V is safe, well-tolerated, and accepted in pregnancy, indicating the need for further studies to evaluate colonization and clinical efficacy.

description: CorALS
study_description: The study introduces CorALS, an open-source framework designed to analyze complex biological systems using large-scale correlation networks. With the emergence of high-dimensional multiomics data, traditional analysis has faced computational challenges. CorALS addresses these challenges by providing algorithms for constructing and analyzing parametric and non-parametric correlation networks, suitable for both personal and high-performance computing. It provided deeper insights into the concerted coordination of biological systems by analysing real-world large-scale multiomics and single-cell datasets.

description: Interactions between Siglec-8 and endogenous sialylated cis ligands restrain cell death induction in human eosinophils and mast cells
study_description: Sialic acid-binding immunoglobulin-like lectin (Siglec)-8 is a sialoside-binding receptor expressed on the surface of eosinophils and mast cells that bears an immunoreceptor tyrosine-based inhibitory motif (ITIM) and an ITIM-like motif in its cytoplasmic domain. On eosinophils that have been primed with IL-5, GM-CSF, or IL-33, antibody ligation of Siglec-8 leads to cell death through a pathway involving the β2 integrin-dependent generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) via NADPH oxidase. In contrast, engagement of Siglec-8 on mast cells has been described to inhibit mast cell activation and mediator release but not impact cell viability. The differences in responses between cytokine-primed and unprimed eosinophils, and between eosinophils and mast cells, to Siglec-8 ligation are not understood. In addition, we have previously found that Siglec-8 binds to sialylated ligands on the surface of the same cell (so-called cis ligands) on eosinophils, preventing interaction with a Siglec-8 ligand in trans. However, the functional relevance of these cis ligands have not been elucidated. We therefore explored the potential influence of cis ligands of Siglec-8 on the surfaces of both eosinophils and mast cells. Removal of sialic acid using exogenous sialidase had profound effects on the consequences of Siglec-8 antibody engagement on both cell types, eliminating the need for cytokine priming of eosinophils to facilitate cell death and enabling Siglec-8-dependent mast cell death without impacting anti-Siglec-8 antibody binding. The cell death process licensed by incubation with sialidase resembled that characterized in IL-5-primed eosinophils, including the upregulation of CD11b, production of ROS, and requirement for the signaling activities of Syk, PI3K, and PLC. These results implicate cis ligands in restraining Siglec-8 function on eosinophils and mast cells and reveal a promising approach to the selective depletion of mast cells in patients with mast cell-mediated diseases.

description: Maternal immune response and placental antibody transfer by trimester of COVID-19 vaccination
study_description: The study characterizes the immune response induced by the three COVID1-9 vaccines, Ad26.COV2.S, mRNA-1273 or BNT162b2 vaccination in pregnant individuals. To further understand the protective effect on the baby, we also evaluated transplacental antibody transfer by profiling maternal and umbilical cord blood in 175 maternal-neonatal dyads. These analyses reveal vaccine-dependent and trimester-dependent antibody response in the mother and fetus, with higher titers and functions by mRNA vaccines, and an increased maternal immune response from the first and third trimester of vaccination. These results provide novel insight into the impact of platform and trimester of vaccination on maternal humoral immune response and transplacental antibody transfer.

description: Immune repertoire sequencing of Coeliac patients
study_description: Immune repertoire sequencing of 12 CeD patients and 8 non-CeD controls.

description: Longitudinal analysis of SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence
study_description: Samples from healthcare workers (HCWs) were collected to assess their seroprevalence using various serology platforms

description: Sex and Gender Differences in Testing, Hospital Admission, Clinical Presentation, and Drivers of Severe Outcomes From COVID-19
study_description: To elucidate features of COVID-19 infection that differ between males and females from diagnosis to outcomes

description: Neutralization Escape by SARS-CoV-2 Omicron Subvariant BA.4.6
study_description: To determine the ability of BA.4.6 to evade neutralizing antibodies that were induced by infection or vaccination.

description: Determinants and Mechanisms of the Low Fusogenicity and High Dependence on Endosomal Entry of Omicron Subvariants
study_description: To investigate the mechanisms governing Omicron subvariant entry.

description: SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant genomic variation associated with breakthrough infection in Northern California: A retrospective cohort study
study_description: To characterize the genomic variation within a circulating variant and identifying potential mutations associated with breakthrough infection among persons with Delta variant SARS-CoV-2 infection

description: Coronavirus Disease 2019 Messenger RNA Vaccine Immunogenicity in Immunosuppressed Individuals
study_description: To assess the effect of immunosuppresive therapy on antibody responses following COVID-19 messenger RNA vaccination

description: Immunogenicity of COVID-19 mRNA Vaccines in Pregnant and Lactating Women
study_description: To evaluate the immunogenicity of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines, including against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern, in pregnant and lactating women.

description: Characterization of immune responses in fully vaccinated individuals after breakthrough infection with the SARS-CoV-2 delta variant
study_description: To evaluate the immune responses in fully vaccinated individuals with or without SARS-CoV-2 breakthrough infection.

description: Neutralization escape of Omicron XBB, BR.2, and BA.2.3.20 subvariants
study_description: To examine the sensitivity of BR.2, BA.2.3.20, and XBB subvariants to neutralization by vaccine- and infection-induced sera samples and compare them to the ancestral D614G, BA.2, and BA.2.75 subvariants.

description: Differential Kinetics of Immune Responses Elicited by Covid-19 Vaccines
study_description: To evaluate antibody and T-cell responses from peak immunity at 2 to 4 weeks after the second immunization in recipients of the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines or after the first immunization in recipients of the Ad26.COV2.S vaccine to 8 months.

description: Right Ventricular Abnormality in Patients Hospitalized With COVID-19 Infection During Omicron Variant Surge.
study_description: To study the association of in-hospital mortality with echocardiographic measures of right ventricular performance during the COVID-19 infection during the Omicron surge in New York City.

description: Coronavirus disease 2019 vaccine response in pregnant and lactating women: a cohort study
study_description: To evaluate the immunogenicity and reactogenicity of coronavirus disease 2019 messenger RNA vaccination in pregnant and lactating women.

description: Methodological approaches to optimize multiplex oral fluid SARS-CoV-2 IgG assay performance and correlation with serologic and neutralizing antibody responses
study_description: To optimize performance of a magnetic microparticle-based multiplex immunoassay (MIA) for SARS-CoV-2 IgG measurement in saliva.

description: Dissecting strategies to tune the therapeutic potential of SARS-CoV-2–specific monoclonal antibody CR3022
study_description: To explore the therapeutic potential of SARS-CoV-2–specific monoclonal antibody CR3022 and study the role of Fc effector function on the response to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: Significant Reduction in Vaccine Induced Antibody Levels and Neutralization Activity Among Healthcare Workers and Nursing Home Residents 6 Months Following Coronavirus Disease 2019 BNT162b2 mRNA Vaccination
study_description: To assess antibody decline following vaccination in Nursinghome residents and health care workers.

description: A Machine Learning Algorithm Predicts Duration of hospitalization in COVID-19 patients.
study_description: To develop machine learning algorithms that predict the likelihood of prolonged length of stay using electronic health record data from 966 COVID-19 patient.

description: Progression and Resolution of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) Infection in Golden Syrian Hamsters
study_description: To characterize progression of disease in depth in a robust coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) animal model

description: 124I-Iodo-DPA-713 Positron Emission Tomography in a Hamster Model of SARS-CoV-2 Infection
study_description: To evaluate the local immune response in a hamster lung model of SARS-CoV-2 infection by pulmonary Positron Emission Tomography with 124I-iodo-DPA-713.

description: Exposure of progressive immune dysfunction by SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia: A prospective cohort study
study_description: To probe the underlying mechanisms of immune dysfunction in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) patients with varying degrees of disease progression by studying both humoral and cellular immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

description: Conflict in the EMS Workforce: An Analysis of an Open-Ended Survey Question Reveals a Complex Assemblage of Stress, Burnout, and Pandemic-Related Factors Influencing Well-Being
study_description: To explore the extent to which added stressors of the pandemic exacerbated EMS workplace conflict.

description: Rhesus H-ARS Dose-Response Relationship
study_description: The objective of the study was to establish a probit survival curve in irradiated rhesus macaque non-human primates (NHP) for 60 days under the same experimental conditions as was used in subsequent studies. Animals received supportive care including antibiotics, fluids, anti-ulcer, anti-emetics, analgesics, nutritional support, and wound disinfection administered according to pre-determined criteria. No blood products were provided.

description: Human in vitro modeling of adjuvants
study_description: Characterization of mechanism of action of adjuvant formulations

description: Multimodal hierarchical classification of CITE-seq data
study_description: We describe MultiModal Classifier Hierarchy (MMoCHi), a marker-based approach for the classification of CITE-seq data, reconciling gene and protein expression without reliance on reference atlases. We benchmark MMoCHi using sorted T lymphocyte subsets and annotate a cross-tissue human immune cell dataset. MMoCHi outperforms leading transcriptome-based classifiers and multimodal unsupervised clustering in its ability to identify immune cell subsets that are not readily resolved and to reveal novel subset markers.

description: Mucosal antibody responses to SARS-CoV-2 booster vaccination and breakthrough infection
study_description: Here, the investigators measured serum IgG, saliva IgG and saliva secretory IgA responses in individuals who experienced breakthrough infections and who received COVID-19 mRNA booster vaccinations.

description: Preconception Genetic Carrier Screening for Miscarriage Risk Assessment: A Bioinformatic Approach to Identifying Candidate Lethal Genes and Variants
study_description: This study explored the influence of known and potential genes on prenatal lethality and preconception genetic carrier screening (PGCS) across diverse populations. Using bioinformatics, researchers identified essential genes for fetal survival, examined variants absent in homozygous states in healthy populations, and estimated heterozygous carrier rates for lethal conditions. A total of 3080 lethal genes were identified, with a high frequency of lethal variants in 163 genes within the general population. These findings highlight the need for a comprehensive, pan-ethnic PGCS panel, incorporating genes associated with miscarriage to enhance prenatal care and prevention efforts across various ethnic groups.

description: Genetic Associations in subjects of anthrax trial [Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed: Human Reactogenicity and Immunogenicity Trial to Address Change in Route of Administration and Dose Reduction (AVA000)]
study_description: Genetic Associations in the AVA000 trial population and functional mechanism of that variation. Keywords in the study are: SNPs, Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA), Illumina BeadChip array, Pyrosequencing, Genotyping, Genetic variation, Saline placebo

description: Effects of Inhibiting Early Inflammation in Kidney Transplant Patients (CTOT-19)
study_description: This is a Phase II, Multicenter, randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled, 2-arm clinical trial of 300 deceased donor kidney transplant recipients. Subjects will be randomized 1:1 to the experimental or control arms (150 subjects per arm).

description: Decay of coronavirus disease 2019 mRNA vaccine-induced immunity in people with HIV
study_description: To analyze humoral and cellular immunity 6 months post COVID-19 mRNA vaccination in people with HIV and healthy donors.

description: Nucleocapsid-specific antibody function is associated with therapeutic benefits from COVID-19 convalescent plasma therapy
study_description: To evaluate the association between clinical benefits of convalescent plasma (CCP) and inflammatory Spike (S) responses and nucleocapsid (N) humoral responses.

description: mRNA-1273 and BNT162b2 mRNA vaccines have reduced neutralizing activity against the SARS-CoV-2 omicron variant
study_description: To evaluate the neutralizing activity of mRNA-1273 and BNT162b2 mRNA vaccines against omicron variant in individuals after initial two-vaccine doses and third dose.

description: Durability of immune responses to the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine
study_description: To measure antibody responses to several SARS-CoV-2 variants of interest in BNT162b2 (Pfizer) mRNA vaccinated individuals at 6 months after the second dose.

description: Rapid decline in vaccine-boosted neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant
study_description: To assess the magnitude and short-term durability of neutralizing antibodies after homologous and heterologous boosting with mRNA and Ad26.COV2.S vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant.

description: Maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection elicits sexually dimorphic placental immune responses
study_description: To assess maternal-fetal antibody transfer, viral-induced placental IFN responses, and the impact of fetal sex in pregnant humans infected with SARS-CoV-2.

description: Infant rhesus macaques immunized against SARS-CoV-2 are protected against heterologous virus challenge 1 year later
study_description: To provide proof of concept that immune responses induced by early-life vaccination would persist and protect from severe disease after high-dose challenge with a heterologous variant 1 year after vaccination.

description: Discovery and intranasal administration of a SARS-CoV-2 broadly acting neutralizing antibody with activity against multiple Omicron subvariants
study_description: To discover and characterize therapeutic antibodies with the breadth and potency of neutralizing activity required to treat newly diagnosed COVID-19 linked to recently emerged variants of concern including Omicron subvariants BA.1, BA.1.1, and BA.2.

description: Antigen-adjuvant interactions, stability, and immunogenicity profiles of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) antigen formulated with aluminum salt and CpG adjuvants
study_description: To elucidate the key interrelationships between antigen-adjuvant interactions, storage stability, and in vivo performance to enable successful formulation development of stable and efficacious subunit vaccines.

description: Simulation and Prediction of the Adaptive Immune Response and Quantification of Early and Adaptive Immune Response Kinetics to Influenza A Virus Infection
study_description: Modeling approaches were combined with experimental data to investigate innate and adaptive immune responses to IAV infection. Mathematical models developed describe the dynamic interactions between influenza virus, target cells, cytotoxic lymphocytes, and virus-specific IgG and IgM. In additon, a two-compartment model developed quantifies the effects of viral replication and adaptive immunity.

description: SARS-CoV-2 infection produces chronic pulmonary epithelial and immune cell dysfunction with fibrosis in mice
study_description: To identify pathways associated with persistent SARS-CoV-2 pulmonary disease and test countermeasures to ameliorate post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2

description: The post-COVID-19 population has a high prevalence of cross-reactive antibodies to spikes from all Orthocoronavirinae genera
study_description: Infection with and vaccination against severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) induces broadly cross-reactive binding antibodies to spikes from a wide range of coronaviruses.

description: Neutralizing antibody responses elicited by SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination wane over time and are boosted by breakthrough infection
study_description: To study if the waning efficacy of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines and emergence of variants resistant to vaccine-induced immunity affects the need for booster vaccine doses and how it might contribute to rates of breakthrough infections, especially in the context of evolving SARS-CoV-2 variants.

description: Nanoalum Formulations Containing Aluminum Hydroxide and CpG 1018TM Adjuvants: The Effect on Stability and Immunogenicity of a Recombinant SARS-CoV-2 RBD Antigen
study_description: To evaluate whether sonication of aluminum hydroxide to the nanometer size range (nanoAH) can further enhance immunogenicity or improve storage stability of recombinant receptor-binding domain (RBD)-based COVID-19 vaccine candidate (RBD-J; RBD-L452K-F490W) with aluminum hydroxide (Alhydrogel®; AH) and CpG 1018™ (CpG) adjuvants.

description: Pandemic Experience of First Responders
study_description: A deeper understanding of the challenges facing first responders during the COVID-19 pandemic

description: Determinants of Neutralizing Antibody Response After SARS CoV-2 Vaccination in Patients With Myeloma
study_description: To evaluate the capacity of vaccine-induced antibodies in myeloma patients to neutralize SARS CoV-2 and its variants.

description: A public vaccine-induced human antibody for SARS-CoV-2

description: Antibodies targeting the neuraminidase active site inhibit influenza H3N2 viruses
study_description: Contemporary influenza A H3N2 viruses circulating since 2016 have acquired a glycosylation site in the neuraminidase in close proximity to the enzymatic active site. Here, we investigate if this S245N glycosylation site, as a result of antigenic evolution, can impact binding and function of human monoclonal antibodies that target the conserved active site.

description: Relationship between Anti-Spike Antibodies and Risk of SARS-CoV-2 Infection in Infants Born to COVID-19 Vaccinated Mothers
study_description: To investigate the relationship between anti-SARS-CoV-2-Spike IgG titers passively transferred to the fetus from maternal vaccination during pregnancy and timing of infant SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: Activity of convalescent and vaccine serum against Omicron
study_description: Omicron hosts an unprecedented number of mutations in its spike gene and early reports have provided evidence for extensive immune escape and reduced vaccine effectiveness. Here we investigated the virus-neutralizing and spike protein-binding activity of sera from convalescent, double mRNA-vaccinated, mRNA-boosted, convalescent double-vaccinated and convalescent boosted individuals against wild-type, Beta (B.1.351) and Omicron SARS-CoV-2 isolates and spike proteins.

description: Ad26 vaccine protects against SARS-CoV-2 severe clinical disease in hamsters
study_description: To assess the clinical and virologic characteristics of high-dose SARS-CoV-2 infection in hamsters and to evaluate the protective efficacy of an adenovirus serotype 26 (Ad26) vector-based vaccine.

description: Ad26.COV2.S and SARS-CoV-2 spike protein ferritin nanoparticle vaccine protect against SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.5 challenge in macaques
study_description: To evaluate the homologous and heterologous regimens consisting of Ad26.COV2.S and SpFN vaccines against a high-dose, mismatched SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.5 challenge in macaques.

description: Comparative performance of between-population vaccine allocation strategies with applications for emerging pandemics
study_description: To examine optimal vaccine allocation decisions across population considering the impact of characteristics of the population, vaccine pathogen, and delivery.

description: Impaired SARS-CoV-2 Variant Neutralization and CD8+ T-cell Responses Following 3 Doses of mRNA Vaccines in Myeloma: Correlation with Breakthrough Infections
study_description: To investigate immune recognition of current VOC including BA.1, BA.2, and BA.5 in patients with multiple myeloma (MM) following 2 or 3 doses of mRNA vaccines.

description: DCVC_0026
study_description: Two immunogens and a negative control were tested in 7 week old female mice primed on day 0, boosted on day 56, and sacrificed on day 71.

description: Anamnestic humoral correlates of immunity across SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern
study_description: To examine anamnestic antibody responses in breakthrough cases to identify antigen targets susceptible to novel monoclonal antibody therapy or vaccination-boosting strategies.

description: SARS-CoV-2 spike E484K mutation reduces antibody neutralisation

description: Impact of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Variants on Short- and Mid-term Cardiac Outcomes in Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children
study_description: To investigate acute cardiac involvement and short- and mid-term cardiac outcomes in children with multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C) that followed 3 different waves (Wuhan, Alpha, and Delta) of the SARS-CoV-2 infection.

description: Development of a universal pentavalent mRNA vaccine against IBVs

We evaluate vaccine candidates based on different target antigens that afford protection against challenge with ancestral and recent influenza B viruses from both antigenic lineages.
